requirement_status.requirement_description: Investment firms seeking authorization must ensure that competent authorities are informed of the identities of all shareholders or members (whether direct or indirect, natural or legal persons) that have qualifying holdings and the amounts of those holdings before authorization can be granted. This disclosure requirement applies to <article_reference article_id="10" regulation_id="02014L0065-20250117" domain="EU"/> and must be completed as a prerequisite to receiving authorization to provide investment services or perform investment activities.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 2.1 states: 'All shareholders with qualifying holdings have been disclosed to the competent authorities as part of our authorization process. The identities and amounts of these holdings are updated quarterly and reported to regulatory authorities.'

requirement_status.requirement_description: Investment firms must ensure they do not have close links with natural or legal persons governed by third country laws that would prevent the effective exercise of supervisory functions by competent authorities. Investment firms must also ensure that any influence exercised by qualifying shareholders or members does not prejudice sound and prudent management of the firm. This requirement applies under <article_reference article_id="10" regulation_id="02014L0065-20250117" domain="EU"/>.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 2.2 Close Links Assessment states: 'The Firm has conducted a comprehensive assessment of close links and confirms: - No close links exist with entities in third countries that would impede supervisory functions - All qualifying shareholders have been vetted for their influence on management - Annual reviews are conducted to ensure continued compliance.'

requirement_status.requirement_description: Natural or legal persons or such persons acting in concert who have decided to acquire, directly or indirectly, a qualifying holding in an investment firm or to further increase such a qualifying holding, where the proportion of voting rights or capital would reach or exceed 20%, 30% or 50% or would make the investment firm their subsidiary, must notify in writing the competent authorities of the investment firm. The notification must indicate the size of the intended holding and include relevant information as referred to in <article_reference article_id="13" regulation_id="02014L0065-20250117" domain="EU"/>.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 3.1 Notification Procedures states: 'Any natural or legal person intending to acquire a qualifying holding must: 1. Submit written notification to competent authorities before acquisition 2. Provide complete information about the size of intended holding 3. Include all relevant information as specified by regulatory requirements. Thresholds requiring notification: - Initial qualifying holding (10% or more) - Increases reaching or exceeding 20%, 30%, or 50% - Any acquisition resulting in the Firm becoming a subsidiary.'

requirement_status.requirement_description: Investment firms must inform the competent authority without delay if they become aware of any acquisitions or disposals of holdings in their capital that cause holdings to exceed or fall below any of the thresholds of 20%, 30% or 50% of voting rights or capital, or that affect subsidiary status.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 3.1 states: 'Thresholds requiring notification: - Initial qualifying holding (10% or more) - Increases reaching or exceeding 20%, 30%, or 50% - Any acquisition resulting in the Firm becoming a subsidiary.' Section 3.2 further states: 'The Firm monitors its shareholder register monthly and will inform competent authorities without delay of any changes crossing the 20%, 30%, or 50% thresholds.'

requirement_status.requirement_description: Competent authorities must acknowledge receipt of notifications from proposed acquirers in writing within two working days following receipt of the notification required under <article_reference article_id="11" regulation_id="02014L0065-20250117" domain="EU"/> or following the subsequent receipt of additional information.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 3.1 (Notification Procedures) of the policy states: 'Any natural or legal person intending to acquire a qualifying holding must: 1. Submit written notification to competent authorities before acquisition...' but there is no mention of the competent authorities' obligation to acknowledge receipt of such notifications in writing within two working days, nor any procedure for ensuring this acknowledgment is provided.
requirement_status.missing_elements: The policy does not specify that competent authorities must acknowledge receipt of notifications from proposed acquirers in writing within two working days following receipt of the notification or additional information, as required by the regulation.
requirement_status.amendments: Amend Section 3.1 to include a requirement that, upon receipt of a notification from a proposed acquirer (or additional information), the competent authorities must provide a written acknowledgment of receipt within two working days. The policy should also outline a process for tracking and confirming such acknowledgments to ensure compliance with the regulatory requirement.

requirement_status.requirement_description: Competent authorities may request any further information necessary to complete the assessment during the assessment period, no later than on the 50th working day of the assessment period. Such requests must be made in writing and specify the additional information needed.
requirement_status.evidence: The policy document does not mention any procedures or commitments regarding the ability of competent authorities to request further information during the assessment period, nor does it specify that such requests must be made in writing and detail the additional information needed.
requirement_status.missing_elements: The policy lacks a provision stating that competent authorities may request further information during the assessment period (no later than the 50th working day), and that such requests must be made in writing and specify the information required.
requirement_status.amendments: Add a section to the policy (e.g., under 'Authorization and Shareholding Disclosure' or 'Regulatory Reporting') stating: 'The Firm acknowledges that competent authorities may request any further information necessary to complete their assessment during the assessment period, provided such requests are made in writing and specify the additional information needed. The Firm will respond promptly to all such requests, particularly those made no later than the 50th working day of the assessment period.'

requirement_status.requirement_description: Competent authorities may extend the interruption period up to 30 working days if the proposed acquirer is a natural or legal person situated or regulated outside the Union, or a natural or legal person not subject to supervision under this Directive or Directives 2009/65/EC, 2009/138/EC or 2013/36/EU.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 3.1 (Notification Procedures) and Section 3.2 (Internal Monitoring) describe the process for notifying competent authorities of acquisitions and changes in qualifying holdings, but there is no mention of the interruption period or the possibility for competent authorities to extend the interruption period up to 30 working days for acquirers situated or regulated outside the Union, or not subject to supervision under the relevant Directives.
requirement_status.missing_elements: The policy does not specify that competent authorities may extend the interruption period up to 30 working days in the cases described by the requirement (i.e., acquirers outside the Union or not subject to supervision under the specified Directives).
requirement_status.amendments: Amend Section 3 (Acquisition and Disposal Notifications) to explicitly state that, in accordance with regulatory requirements, competent authorities may extend the interruption period up to 30 working days if the proposed acquirer is a natural or legal person situated or regulated outside the Union, or not subject to supervision under Directive 2014/65/EU, 2009/65/EC, 2009/138/EC, or 2013/36/EU.

requirement_status.requirement_description: If competent authorities decide to oppose a proposed acquisition upon completion of the assessment, they must inform the proposed acquirer in writing within two working days and not exceeding the assessment period, providing the reasons for that decision. Subject to national law, an appropriate statement of the reasons may be made accessible to the public at the request of the proposed acquirer.
requirement_status.evidence: The policy document describes procedures for notification of proposed acquisitions (Section 3.1), monitoring of shareholdings (Section 3.2), and general regulatory reporting (Section 10), but does not address the process or obligations of competent authorities in the event of an opposition to a proposed acquisition. There is no mention of informing the proposed acquirer in writing within two working days, providing reasons for the decision, or making a statement of reasons accessible to the public at the request of the acquirer.
requirement_status.missing_elements: The policy does not specify that, if competent authorities oppose a proposed acquisition, they must inform the proposed acquirer in writing within two working days (and not exceeding the assessment period), provide the reasons for the decision, or make an appropriate statement of reasons accessible to the public at the request of the acquirer.
requirement_status.amendments: Add a section outlining the procedure to be followed if competent authorities oppose a proposed acquisition, including: (1) a requirement to inform the proposed acquirer in writing within two working days and not exceeding the assessment period; (2) an obligation to provide the reasons for the decision; and (3) a provision, subject to national law, to make an appropriate statement of the reasons accessible to the public at the request of the proposed acquirer.

requirement_status.requirement_description: If competent authorities do not oppose a proposed acquisition within the assessment period in writing, the acquisition shall be deemed to be approved.
requirement_status.evidence: The policy document details notification procedures for acquisitions (Section 3.1), including the requirement to notify competent authorities and provide relevant information. However, it does not specify what happens if the competent authorities do not respond within the assessment period, nor does it state that the acquisition shall be deemed approved in such a case.
requirement_status.missing_elements: The policy does not state that if competent authorities do not oppose a proposed acquisition within the assessment period in writing, the acquisition shall be deemed to be approved.
requirement_status.amendments: Amend Section 3.1 to include a statement such as: 'If the competent authorities do not oppose a proposed acquisition in writing within the regulatory assessment period, the acquisition shall be deemed to be approved in accordance with applicable regulations.'

requirement_status.requirement_description: Competent authorities may fix a maximum period for concluding the proposed acquisition and extend it where appropriate.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 3.1 (Notification Procedures) and Section 3.2 (Internal Monitoring) describe the process for notifying competent authorities of proposed acquisitions and monitoring shareholdings, but there is no mention of the competent authorities fixing a maximum period for concluding the proposed acquisition or the possibility of extending such a period.
requirement_status.missing_elements: The policy does not state that competent authorities may fix a maximum period for concluding the proposed acquisition, nor does it mention the possibility of extending this period where appropriate.
requirement_status.amendments: Amend Section 3 (Acquisition and Disposal Notifications) to include a statement such as: 'Upon notification of a proposed acquisition, the Firm acknowledges that competent authorities may fix a maximum period for concluding the acquisition process, and that this period may be extended by the authorities where appropriate, in accordance with applicable regulatory requirements.'

requirement_status.requirement_description: Member States may not impose requirements for the notification to and approval by the competent authorities of direct or indirect acquisitions of voting rights or capital that are more stringent than those set out in this Directive.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 3.1 of the policy states: 'Any natural or legal person intending to acquire a qualifying holding must: 1. Submit written notification to competent authorities before acquisition 2. Provide complete information about the size of intended holding 3. Include all relevant information as specified by regulatory requirements.' The policy also specifies the notification thresholds (10%, 20%, 30%, 50%) in line with the Directive, and there is no indication of more stringent requirements than those set out in the Directive.

requirement_status.requirement_description: Proposed acquirers must ensure they meet suitability criteria when seeking to acquire qualifying holdings in investment firms. The proposed acquirer must maintain good reputation, demonstrate financial soundness appropriate to the investment firm's business type, and ensure that any persons who will direct the business have appropriate reputation and experience. The proposed acquirer must also ensure the investment firm will be able to comply with prudential requirements under <article_reference article_id="13" regulation_id="02014L0065-20250117" domain="EU"/> and applicable directives including Directives 2002/87/EC and 2013/36/EU, with a group structure that enables effective supervision and information exchange among competent authorities. Additionally, the proposed acquirer must not be involved in money laundering or terrorist financing activities as defined in Article 1 of Directive 2005/60/EC, and the acquisition must not increase such risks.
requirement_status.evidence: The policy document provides for disclosure and vetting of qualifying shareholders (Section 2.1, 2.2), notification procedures (Section 3), capital requirements (Section 4), governance and oversight (Section 9), and compliance framework (Section 5). However, it does not explicitly address the suitability criteria for proposed acquirers, such as the requirement for good reputation, financial soundness, or the absence of involvement in money laundering or terrorist financing. There is also no explicit reference to ensuring that persons directing the business have appropriate reputation and experience, nor is there a clear statement on group structure enabling effective supervision and information exchange, or compliance with prudential requirements under Article 13 of Directive 2014/65/EU and Directives 2002/87/EC and 2013/36/EU.
requirement_status.missing_elements:
1. Explicit requirement for proposed acquirers to demonstrate good reputation and financial soundness.
2. Assessment of reputation and experience of persons directing the business post-acquisition.
3. Statement on group structure enabling effective supervision and information exchange among competent authorities.
4. Explicit commitment to compliance with prudential requirements under Article 13 of Directive 2014/65/EU and Directives 2002/87/EC and 2013/36/EU.
5. Confirmation that proposed acquirers are not involved in money laundering or terrorist financing, and that the acquisition will not increase such risks.
requirement_status.amendments:
1. Add a section requiring all proposed acquirers to provide evidence of good reputation and financial soundness, including background checks and financial statements.
2. Require due diligence on the reputation and experience of any persons who will direct the business following an acquisition.
3. Include a policy statement ensuring the group structure will allow for effective supervision and information exchange among competent authorities.
4. Explicitly reference compliance with prudential requirements under Article 13 of Directive 2014/65/EU and Directives 2002/87/EC and 2013/36/EU.
5. Add a requirement for acquirers to declare and provide evidence that they are not involved in money laundering or terrorist financing, and that the acquisition will not increase such risks.

requirement_status.requirement_description: Proposed acquirers must provide complete and proportionate information necessary for prudential assessment when notifying competent authorities of proposed acquisitions under <article_reference article_id="13" regulation_id="02014L0065-20250117" domain="EU"/>. The information must be adapted to the nature of the proposed acquirer and the proposed acquisition, and must be relevant for prudential assessment purposes. Acquirers should consult the publicly available list of required information specified by Member States.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 3.1 Notification Procedures states: 'Any natural or legal person intending to acquire a qualifying holding must: 1. Submit written notification to competent authorities before acquisition 2. Provide complete information about the size of intended holding 3. Include all relevant information as specified by regulatory requirements.' However, the policy does not specify that the information provided must be proportionate and adapted to the nature of the acquirer and the acquisition, nor does it reference consultation of the publicly available list of required information specified by Member States.
requirement_status.missing_elements: The policy does not explicitly require that the information provided be proportionate and adapted to the nature of the acquirer and the acquisition. It also does not mention the obligation to consult the publicly available list of required information specified by Member States.
requirement_status.amendments: Amend Section 3.1 to explicitly state that proposed acquirers must provide information that is complete, proportionate, and adapted to the nature of both the acquirer and the proposed acquisition, as required for prudential assessment. Add a requirement that acquirers must consult and comply with the publicly available list of required information specified by the relevant Member State when preparing their notification.

requirement_status.requirement_description: Any entity seeking authorisation as an investment firm must meet its obligations under Directive 97/9/EC at the time of authorisation, as verified by the competent authority. For structured deposits, this obligation is satisfied when the structured deposit is issued by a credit institution that is a member of a deposit guarantee scheme recognised under Directive 2014/49/EU.
requirement_status.evidence: The policy document does not mention Directive 97/9/EC (the Investor Compensation Scheme Directive) or any arrangements for investor compensation. It also does not address structured deposits or confirm that any structured deposits are issued by a credit institution that is a member of a deposit guarantee scheme under Directive 2014/49/EU.
requirement_status.missing_elements: No reference to compliance with Directive 97/9/EC or arrangements for investor compensation. No mention of structured deposits or compliance with Directive 2014/49/EU for such products.
requirement_status.amendments: The policy should explicitly state how Falcon Capital Management Ltd. meets its obligations under Directive 97/9/EC, including details of membership in an investor compensation scheme or equivalent arrangements. If the firm offers structured deposits, it should confirm that these are issued by a credit institution that is a member of a deposit guarantee scheme recognized under Directive 2014/49/EU. Add a section on investor compensation and structured deposit compliance to the policy.

requirement_status.requirement_description: Investment firms must maintain sufficient initial capital in accordance with the requirements of Article 9 of Directive (EU) 2019/2034 of the European Parliament and of the Council, having regard to the nature of the investment service or activity in question, as a prerequisite for obtaining authorization from competent authorities.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 4.1 Initial Capital: 'The Firm maintains initial capital of â‚¬5 million, exceeding the minimum requirements for our authorized activities: Trading for own account, Portfolio management, Investment advice.'

requirement_status.requirement_description: Investment firms must establish adequate policies and procedures sufficient to ensure compliance of the firm including its managers, employees and tied agents with its obligations under <article_reference article_id="16" regulation_id="Directive 2014/65/EU" domain="EU"/> as well as appropriate rules governing personal transactions by such persons.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 5.1 Compliance Framework states: 'The Firm has established: - Compliance Department: Independent function reporting directly to the Board - Policies and Procedures: Comprehensive framework covering all regulated activities - Personal Account Dealing Policy: Mandatory for all staff, managers, and tied agents - Training Program: Annual compliance training for all personnel.' This demonstrates that the firm has adequate policies and procedures to ensure compliance with its obligations under Directive 2014/65/EU Article 16, including rules governing personal transactions by managers, employees, and tied agents.

requirement_status.requirement_description: Investment firms must maintain and operate effective organisational and administrative arrangements with a view to taking all reasonable steps designed to prevent conflicts of interest as defined in <article_reference article_id="23" regulation_id="Directive 2014/65/EU" domain="EU"/> from adversely affecting the interests of its clients.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 5.2 Conflict of Interest Management states: 'We maintain robust arrangements to identify, prevent, and manage conflicts of interest: - Conflicts of Interest Register updated quarterly - Chinese walls between advisory and proprietary trading - Disclosure procedures for unavoidable conflicts - Annual review of conflict management effectiveness.' This demonstrates that the firm has effective organisational and administrative arrangements in place to take all reasonable steps to prevent conflicts of interest from adversely affecting client interests, as required by Article 23 of Directive 2014/65/EU.

requirement_status.requirement_description: Investment firms must take reasonable steps to ensure continuity and regularity in the performance of investment services and activities. To that end, the investment firm must employ appropriate and proportionate systems, including information and communication technology ('ICT') systems that are set up and managed in accordance with Article 7 of Regulation (EU) 2022/2554 of the European Parliament and of the Council, as well as appropriate and proportionate resources and procedures.
requirement_status.evidence:
Section 5.3 Business Continuity: 'Our business continuity plan includes: Redundant data centers with real-time replication; Documented procedures for service continuity; Annual disaster recovery testing; Service level agreements with critical vendors.'

Additionally: 'While we have comprehensive ICT systems, specific alignment with Regulation (EU) 2022/2554 requirements is currently under review and will be implemented by Q3 2024.'

Section 12 Implementation Timeline: 'Q3: Full DORA compliance.'
requirement_status.missing_elements: The policy does not currently confirm that ICT systems are set up and managed in accordance with Article 7 of Regulation (EU) 2022/2554 (DORA). It states that alignment is under review and will be implemented by Q3 2024, indicating that full compliance is not yet achieved.
requirement_status.amendments: The policy should explicitly state that ICT systems are already set up and managed in accordance with Article 7 of Regulation (EU) 2022/2554. The firm should accelerate its review and implementation process, and update the policy to confirm current compliance, not just future plans. Additionally, the policy should reference specific procedures and controls that ensure ICT systems meet DORA requirements, including governance, risk management, and incident reporting as per Article 7.

requirement_status.requirement_description: When relying on a third party for the performance of operational functions which are critical for the provision of continuous and satisfactory service to clients and the performance of investment activities on a continuous and satisfactory basis, investment firms must take reasonable steps to avoid undue additional operational risk. Outsourcing of important operational functions may not be undertaken in such a way as to impair materially the quality of its internal control and the ability of the supervisor to monitor the firm's compliance with all obligations.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 5.3 Business Continuity states: 'Our business continuity plan includes: Redundant data centers with real-time replication; Documented procedures for service continuity; Annual disaster recovery testing; Service level agreements with critical vendors.' However, there is no explicit mention of a policy or procedures specifically addressing the avoidance of undue additional operational risk when outsourcing critical or important operational functions, nor is there a statement ensuring that outsourcing does not impair internal controls or supervisory oversight. The policy also notes, 'specific alignment with Regulation (EU) 2022/2554 requirements is currently under review and will be implemented by Q3 2024.'
requirement_status.missing_elements: The policy does not explicitly state that the firm takes reasonable steps to avoid undue additional operational risk when outsourcing critical functions, nor does it confirm that outsourcing will not materially impair internal controls or supervisory oversight. There is also no detailed framework for assessing and managing outsourcing risks as required by the regulation.
requirement_status.amendments: Amend the policy to include a dedicated section on outsourcing of critical or important operational functions. This section should: (1) require risk assessments before entering into outsourcing arrangements; (2) mandate that outsourcing must not impair the firm's internal controls or the supervisor's ability to monitor compliance; (3) outline ongoing monitoring and review of outsourced providers; and (4) reference compliance with all relevant regulatory requirements, including Regulation (EU) 2022/2554. Ensure these measures are implemented and documented before Q3 2024.

requirement_status.requirement_description: Investment firms must arrange for records to be kept of all services, activities and transactions undertaken by it which shall be sufficient to enable the competent authority to fulfil its supervisory tasks and to perform the enforcement actions under <article_reference article_id="16" regulation_id="Directive 2014/65/EU" domain="EU"/>, Regulation (EU) No 600/2014, Directive 2014/57/EU and Regulation (EU) No 596/2014, and in particular to ascertain that the investment firm has complied with all obligations including those with respect to clients or potential clients and to the integrity of the market.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 6.1 General Record Keeping states: 'The Firm maintains records of: - All client transactions and services - Internal compliance monitoring - Board and committee minutes - Risk assessments and controls. Records are retained for a minimum of 5 years (7 years for certain categories).' Section 10 Regulatory Reporting further confirms: 'The Firm submits all required reports to competent authorities including: - Transaction reporting under MiFIR - Periodic compliance assessments - Annual audited accounts - Shareholding structure updates.'

requirement_status.requirement_description: Investment firms must ensure that records include the recording of telephone conversations or electronic communications relating to, at least, transactions concluded when dealing on own account and the provision of client order services that relate to the reception, transmission and execution of client orders.
requirement_status.evidence:
6.2 Communications Recording
The Firm records all telephone conversations related to:
- Proprietary trading activities
- Client order execution
Electronic communications (email, chat) recording for client orders is currently being implemented with expected completion by March 2024.
requirement_status.missing_elements: The policy states that electronic communications recording for client orders is not yet fully implemented, with completion expected by March 2024. Therefore, at present, the requirement to record electronic communications relating to transactions and client order services is only partially met.
requirement_status.amendments: To fully meet the requirement, the firm should ensure that electronic communications (such as email and chat) relating to transactions concluded when dealing on own account and the provision of client order services are recorded immediately. The policy should be updated to confirm that both telephone and electronic communications are currently being recorded, not just planned for future implementation.

requirement_status.requirement_description: When holding financial instruments belonging to clients, investment firms must make adequate arrangements so as to safeguard the ownership rights of clients, especially in the event of the investment firm's insolvency, and to prevent the use of a client's financial instruments on own account except with the client's express consent.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 7.1 states: 'When holding client financial instruments, we: - Maintain segregated custody accounts - Conduct daily reconciliations - Use only approved third-party custodians - Obtain explicit consent for any use of client assets.' Section 7.2 further clarifies that client funds are held in segregated accounts and never used for the Firm's own purposes. Section 7.3 prohibits title transfer arrangements with retail clients. These provisions collectively address safeguarding ownership rights, segregation in insolvency, and prohibition of use without express consent.

requirement_status.requirement_description: When holding funds belonging to clients, investment firms must make adequate arrangements to safeguard the rights of clients and, except in the case of credit institutions, prevent the use of client funds for its own account.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 7.2 Client Funds: 'The Firm does not hold client money directly. All client funds are: - Held in segregated accounts at authorized credit institutions - Subject to trust arrangements - Never used for the Firm's own purposes'

requirement_status.requirement_description: Investment firms must not conclude title transfer financial collateral arrangements with retail clients for the purpose of securing or covering present or future, actual or contingent or prospective obligations of clients.
requirement_status.evidence: Section 7.3 Title Transfer Arrangements: 'The Firm is prohibited from entering into title transfer financial collateral arrangements with retail clients under any circumstances.'

requirement_status.requirement_description: Investment firms that engage in algorithmic trading must implement and maintain effective systems and risk controls appropriate to their business operations. These systems must ensure trading systems are resilient and have sufficient capacity in accordance with the requirements laid down in Chapter II of Regulation (EU) 2022/2554, are subject to appropriate trading thresholds and limits, and prevent the sending of erroneous orders or systems functioning in a way that may create or contribute to a disorderly market.
requirement_status.evidence:
8. Algorithmic Trading Controls
The Firm currently does not engage in algorithmic trading but recognizes the need to establish policies before commencing such activities.
requirement_status.missing_elements: The policy does not describe any systems or risk controls for algorithmic trading, nor does it address trading system resilience, capacity, trading thresholds, limits, or mechanisms to prevent erroneous orders as required by Regulation (EU) 2022/2554. The policy only acknowledges the need to establish such controls if algorithmic trading is commenced in the future.
requirement_status.amendments: To meet the requirement, the policy should include a detailed section outlining the systems and risk controls that will be implemented for algorithmic trading. This should cover: (1) ensuring trading system resilience and sufficient capacity, (2) setting appropriate trading thresholds and limits, and (3) implementing controls to prevent erroneous orders or disorderly market conditions, in accordance with Chapter II of Regulation (EU) 2022/2554. The policy should also specify ongoing monitoring, testing, and review procedures for these controls.
